title: Will a Spanish prime minister win a vote of confidence before 1 October 2016?
preds: Adjusting downwards for passing of time
right. previous was way to positive and i forgot to adjust

http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/spains-regional-elections-reaffirm-rajoy-in-galicia/Acting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy’s conservative Popular Party got a boost in regional elections Sunday, while the opposition Socialists lost ground.
A Spanish opinion poll indicates that another national election wouldn't break the political stalemate that has left the country without a government for more than nine months.
No progress and pretty much no time left either.
Messy nomination scandal rocks Spain’s ruling party

Deutsche Welle Website. (2016). December election beckons as MPs scupper PM Rajoy's bid to form government Deutsche Welle. Retrieved from
http://www.dw.com/en/december-election-beckons-as-mps-scupper-pm-rajoys-bid-to-form-government/a-19517110
Spanish MPs have rejected acting PM Mariano Rajoy's bid to form a government. The next step is in two days with a second parliamentary vote, but this year's third election now looks likely to be held at Christmas.
Consensus is at 6%, and given recent news
Highly unlikely as long as Rajoy is around.

PSOE voted against and PP just reaffirmed Rajoy as their leader (http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/09/04/483083/Spain-Mariano-Rajoy-attempts-formation-government-election), so dropping forecast further. If deadline was 31st of October, it would be trickier, but it looks like focus will be elsewhere between now and Oct 1 - regional elections etc

It is instructive (for me) to review my forecasts at this point. In mid-July, I started as an optimist, believing that the PSOE cannot afford to be blamed for causing new elections and will yield, probably by a few abstentions. However, at that time I didn't know (i) about the regional elections on Sep 25, and (ii) that even if the Aug 31-Sep 2 attempt to form a government fails, there will be another chance (by Oct 31) to form a government before new elections are triggered. The turning point for me was the PSOE leadership decision to wait out the regional elections. Then I realized that a government before that will be seen as a defeat for the PSOE, so they cannot afford to allow that (unless there were a revolt, but this didn't happen).
Adjusting for latest developments - the 2 Rajoy defeats this week

Mariano Rajoy, the caretaker leader of a country without a government for over eight months, lost a second vote of confidence in parliament on Friday, with lawmakers once again rejecting his bid for a new term as Spain’s prime minister.

No abstentions: no government.  Small window remains for the last week of September, after the regional elections, but negotiations can continue until the deadline at the end of October.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-idUSKCN1181AB?il=0
This article offers an excellent up close look at why I changed my forecast so dramatically. http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/220772/spain%E2%80%99s-socialists-say-no-to-rajoy-as-pm

Next election will be on Christmas day if a bill isn't passed to avoid that.  Rajoy is sort of holding Christmas hostage to try to scare somebody--anybody--into abstaining in the next vote.  If that doesn't work, PP will probably let the law change go through, but who knows?
Silly me. I underestimated the ability of politician to be politician.

If I am not mistaken, Sep 2 is not the last chance to vote a government in and avoid elections - that deadline is October 31. The PSOE will have another chance after the regional elections in late September - and if things go badly for them, indeed an abstention of a few MPs can be the way to go. But now - as the PSOE leadership has made the decision to wait for the regional elections and not allow a Rajoy government meanwhile - wouldn't an abstention that allows a PP/Ciudadanos government in be seen as a defeat of Sanchez and the whole leadership? It may still happen, but are the chances large?
Friday second vote. Should work. Only a few extra votes needed. Under pressure everything becomes fluid.

Socialists are pursuing a risky "no" strategy.  They are likely to lose by-elections in Galicia and Basque provinces prior to what would be a third round of elections (on 18th or 25th of December), and currently polls show that, in the event of a third election, they are running well behind their national performance in the last round of elections.    There will be good pressure on Sanchez from MPs in vulnerable districts to allow abstentions at the second investiture vote coming up this week and thus postpone new elections until the Spring of 2017 (at least), or until such time as another PP corruption scandal erupts.  For now, I am thinking there is still a 50/50 chance Sanchez allows MPs to vote their conscience and abstain if necessary.   If Sanchez votes "no" at the second investiture later this week and if the PSOE loses in the by-elections this fall, there is a very good chance someone else will be leading the PSOE at the December elections.

Spain's acting Prime Minister, Mariano Rajoy, has lost a parliamentary bid for a second term in office.
The failure to secure the position deepens the country's political crisis after two inconclusive elections.
Mr Rajoy, leader of the conservative Popular Party (PP), secured the backing of 170 representatives in the 350-strong assembly after failing to win support from the opposition.

Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, called on opposition parties on Tuesday to allow him to form a new government or risk jeopardizing Spain’s democratic system and economic recovery.Presenting his government program before Parliament, Mr. Rajoy said that Spain faced one of the most critical challenges of its four decades of modern democracy and could not afford to prolong a political deadlock that has already produced two inconclusive elections since last December.

-2 from 37
Considering the actual situation at the parliement it would be surprising that PSOE and Podemos vote yes at a vote for confidence.
The rhetoric of those party suggest more the tone of an another election. [1]

Rajoy says new government more a wish than a fact...
https://www.thespainreport.com/articles/873-160827132841-rajoy-says-new-government-more-a-wish-than-a-fact
FYI, I have asked the GJ Open team if there was a chance that the enddate of this question would shift to October 31, the official enddate for this round of negotiations. Their reply says 'No':

The Big R just did a deal with the "Ciudadnos" giving him 170 out of the 176 needed, so he needs a little help as this article suggests.  
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-28/rajoy-seals-pact-with-ciudadanos-ahead-of-spain-confidence-vote
There is a small chance that there will be some movement in the position of PSOE after the regional elections. But I don't think Rajoy will succeed on August 31, or before October 1.

I am joining the pessimists. According to media reports,  Rajoy and Rivera seem to be going through the motions of putting a coalition together while downplaying their own chances of a win. The PSOE has decided to wait out the regional elections in late September.
Rajoy is finally getting some positive commitments; he's now got Cuidadanos' 32 for a total of 170.  He's only 6 votes away from success, and there's 19 votes in the small parties.

A good chance Rajoy will skate by when the second vote is held next week.   The Socialists are not going to do well if there is a third round of elections-   PP and Citizens will likely do slightly better.  Is the fear of a third straight defeat enough to cause Sanchez to allow a handful of MPs to be absent or abstain during next week's vote?   I think the Socialists have a better shot of drawing attention to themselves in a positive way by opposing and critiquing a PP/C government than they do by being seen as intransigent by voters tired of this saga.  Moreover, they can chose the time and manner of the demise of the minority government (as it would need Socialist support in a confidence vote).   There is bound to be another PP scandal in the press- give Rajoy his rope.    (Note that for his part, Rajoy is happy to go to a third round, particularly if the Socialists look like the bad guys and he looks more like a statesman for agreeing the pact with Citizens and consenting to some mild anti-corruption measures and judicial reform).

Rajoy believes a government, at this point, is "more of a wish":
http://www.thelocal.es/20160828/rajoy-says-forming-new-government-a-wish
Come the moment of truth, I think somebody somewhere will yield to pressure and will make a deal happen, I think there are slightly more odds for that.

http://elpais.com/elpais/2016/08/26/inenglish/1472198928_086219.html
Odds are this deal will collapse, although that it wouldn't matter anyway without an injection of second-round abstentions which are not available.  Rajoy has convinced himself that PP will do better in the Advent elections.  He may be right, but they are still not likely to win enough seats to be the government without securing some playmates.  Since nobody wants to play with him, look for some more elections around Mardi Gras.

Looks like the outcome of this round of negotiations will be decided between 1 and 31 October: http://www.politico.eu/article/spains-socialist-revenge-drama-mariano-rajoy-pedro-sanchez-socialist-workers-party/

Whatever joint scam the PP and Ciudadanos were almost agreed on looks like it's dissolving.  Meanwhile, today's Big Reform proposed by PSOE is aimed only at making sure the next round of elections, apparently now regarded as inevitable, will not occur on Christmas Day.  They appear to have the votes to pass this, although there are procedural things PP could do to hold it up or kill it.  After all, if elections cannot be on Christmas Day, Rajoy loses leverage in trying to coerce somebody--anybody--into taking a dive to avoid new elections.
After two elections you cannot really go back for a third.  If they manage to conclude coalition talks and do a vote before oct 1st.. pooh. holidays over in september. why not.
It sounded like there was finally some movement towards forming a government, but it seems that the momentum has been lost and there is still a 7 vote gap.  Lowering from 88 to 77.

PSOE seem determined (http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2016/08/21/actualidad/1471800591_136601.html in spanish) not to support Rajoy at the second vote contrary to my assumption, although not entirely sure what they are playing for. Focus then goes to Sept 25 for regional elections making the Oct 1 deadline difficult to beat. Dropping my forecast to 12%.

Dropping forecast.  If the votes of confidence both fail; two months of negotiations are possible before the third set of elections are required.  --- Closing date on this question is Oct. 1 -- There will still be a possible month of additional negotiations beyond rhe closing of this question..  
Raising forecast if the question is extended to the end of the possible negotiating period.

Not only no progress, but backpedaling.  Late reports say PP didn't even talk about the Ciudadanos conditions for a playdate.  Not clear what they could have talked about instead, but the fruitless vote seems to be set for 30 August.  This will be followed by another fruitless vote, and then more elections, around Christmas.

PSOE lost votes in second election.
PP and C's deal leave the combination about 7 seats short of a majority.
Suspect PSOE will need to abstain in the upcoming vote or risk a further loss in a 3rd election.
PP will likely be a tough negotiator as PSOE seems to have the most to lose.

So far everybody agrees that the impasse is somebody else's fault.  The position of each party leader is approximately, "If everybody else would be as reasonable as I am, this would be over.  I am a reasonable person standing firmly on principle, but everybody else is just being stubborn and selfish."

Looks like Rajoy's chances have gone up. He can either scrape an ad-hoc majority with some regional parties, or hope that a number of PSOE MPs will abstain in the second vote, even if most of  PSOE MPs  vote against him. Incidentally, this second scenario could be the face-saving way out for Sanchez, allowing him to respect his party vote in July while not forcing third elections. He must realize that if the PSOE is seen as being responsible for yet another round of elections, they will be heavily punished by voters.

http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-18/spanish-liberal-says-rajoy-accepted-conditions-for-support. Bumping up forecast. PSOE will vote against them in first vote, but the probability that they abstain in the second vote must be high at this stage, putting it at 82%. If Sanchez did vote against, he would be risking an immediate leadership challenge, which would still result in a PP government although not in timeframe of this question.

Apparently Rajoy has accepted the demands from Ciudadanos after all. Pressure is on the PSOE now. Will they abstain, or will there be a third round of elections, possible on christmas day? Well played.

Spain's acting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy got the green light from his conservative People's Party (PP) to negotiate with centrist rival Ciudadanos with the aim of forming a government.

So far every party involved in this fiasco has said the situation would sort itself out right away as long as one or more other parties would please cave in.  This is not a formula for successful negotiation.

In the ordinary course of events, "news" implies that something that happened recently is different to what's been happening.  In that sense, no news on this topic: Everyone is setting conditions they know the other parties won't meet, and even if they did there would still be fresh elections with much the same result as the last two.  ¡El Día de la Marmota siempre!

'"The federal committee debated and unanimously approved voting 'no' to the reappointment of Rajoy", PSOE spokesman Óscar López said during a radio interview with Cadena SER on Thursday morning.

Spain's liberal Ciudadanos party said on Tuesday it was open to supporting a conservative-led administration if acting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy agreed first to a package of political reforms.

MADRID — Spain’s political parties have not come to an agreement on creating a coalition government that would end seven months of political deadlock, the country’s acting prime minister said on Wednesday, potentially forcing an unprecedented third round of national elections.
Nobody wants new elections.  Nobody is willing to do what is necessary to avoid them.  Nobody thinks new elections will yield a different result.

PSOE performed badly in the latest CIS polls, while support for PP holds firm (and in any new election they would likely end up with more seats than they have currently).    The better strategy  (than a third round of elections) for the PSOE might be to abstain in a confidence vote, allow the PP to run a minority government and then hope a controversial issue arises where the PSOE can try to topple the government on principle and attract more support.
I still believe that a government is more likely than new elections, but time is running out...

"If circumstances change," PSOE might let PP form a government.  The changed circumstances appear to be the same ones that haven't changed yet.  Perhaps a squadron of pigs flying over Madrid might do it....

Dropping below 50%, at least until someone shows a willingness to bend. A third election would surely prove just as inconclusive as the first two, though I suspect the trend we saw in June's rerun would continue, with PP building its vote and PSOE losing theirs. Do the Socialists really want to try again? 
I suppose a quick resolution is possible if Rajoy steps aside, but why would he? The longer this goes on, the stronger his position may become.
Hard to see how the best interests of Spain are being served by this standoff, but a rocky coalition may not be any better.

--although PP only won 137 seats in the current parliament, Anta Pastor (PP) was recently elected as "Speaker" with 169 votes.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-election-rajoy-idUSKCN0ZD0SY

Current deadlock in negotiations might make it less likely that a PM will win a confidence vote by October. However, the alternatives and potential benefits to all the parties of putting a stable government in place may outweigh this. Podemos failed to gain as much support as they had hoped in the last elections and some suggest that they are losing momentum; the last thing they want now is another election which, if they are blamed for the current deadlock, could even see them go backwards. The socialists want to gain the upper hand on Podemos, but tend to consider that their best chance of doing so may come in a few months time (following a solid record of attacking a potential centre-right minority government) rather than now. And the Popular Party believe they have a right to govern as a minority, so are likely to seek a vote-by-vote agreement with other parties.

If party discipline is still accurate, and i believe so, 
and 
the more you have players the more it is difficult to manage coalition
then there is not a lot of possibilities:

176 is the number needed for a majority. Both the right and the left could form government, but PP failed to form a government for these last several months and 2 elections. I give the Right 0% chance because of prior failure.That leaves only the Left: Socialists and Podemos. They have 159 seats, need 17 more.

Based on today's more or less surprising result, somebody will want to hop into bed with PP.  Trouble is except for PSOE nobody has enough seats to put them over the top.  Somebody could agree to go along with a PP-Ciudadanos government issue by issue, or it may be time for the much-touted PP-PSOE Grand Coalition.

I think that even if the PP doesn't win an absolute majority (and I think it more likely than the polls right now), that the politicians will not be able to go back to the face the voters again so soon and a deal will get hammered out. I think there would be a voter rebellion if they went back for a third time. Many voters would quite reasonably vote against whomever was elected in the hopes of getting a more cooperative person in there. At the end of the day, the most important job to any politician is his or her own.

Since like 1952, I have been really good at predicting election outcomes in many different countries.  This year it has all gone to hell--Peru, Philippines, Trump, and now Brexit--but I notice I am not alone.  So on the bright side, I don't think the problem is that I am olde (although I am).

It is unlikely that the upcoming elections will give any single party an absolute majority (although there are some who are predicting this). However, with the centre-right Popular Party declining in popularity (ironically...), a left-wing bloc could well command close to 50% support. The left-wing parties are much more likely  than the right-wing PP to do a deal with the Catalan and/or Basque nationalist parties, which *could* give them enough support for a working government (albeit at some cost - the nationalists are likely to drive a hard bargain, and are less concerned than the others about the political process stalling, since this ultimately aids their cause).

It’s even less likely that Spain will face a third election. In 168 years of democratic history in Europe, countries had to go to the polls a third time within three consecutive years (or less) only six times (i.e., Denmark, Greece, Ireland, Moldova, Spain and the U.K.). For this reason, we should expect Spain to be able to form a new government after these elections.
I don't think they will risk sending the Spanish electorate to the polls yet again.

Embarrassingly, in trying to simplify the question I managed, through omission, to forecast the probability of a left wing coalition outright majority at 0. Due to the fact that the answer matched my gut feel and the consensus, I didn't probe deeper, even though I had a nagging feeling something was wrong with my forecast.
The next elections will probably yield a victory for the former party in the goverment, not major but it will let them to form a government with another party like Ciudadanos.
Just using the current GJ consensus as my initial prior.
Everybody says they don't want another deadlock.  However, everybody's solution is for somebody else (or everybody else) to take a dive:

there are two ways to look at this question: do the parties see a need for compromise in the face of the potential collapse of the EU or do they see an opportunity to advance their interests. This is a coin flip as I have no confidence in either position at this point, but lean towards "no" until more information comes around.
This is not based on any actual data, but I feel as though this Brexit brouhaha correlates with the approval ratings of the various European head of states.

The three mainstream parties (PP, PSOE, and C's) have all the incentives to reach an agreement. Too many local and regional initiatives have been postponed due to the lack of central government. Also there is a pressure form the EC to form a stable government to continue with the requested reforms. 
In consequence an agreement between the three forces probably with leaded by Ciudadanos is the most probable scenario

The previous vote was a protest of the governments' harsh measures to correct the economy.  While it has not been a perfect recovery things have continued to improve to the point at which the former government and prime minister will get enough votes this time to form a government.  Interesting how this vote and the UK vote on the EU may affect the future i.e. Scotland and Catalonia both may continue push for seperation depending on these votes.

A few random thoughts: Can't help thinking that the will of the people must play second fiddle to the will of the parties. While voters prepare for an election rerun, the major parties will, no doubt, be neck deep in negotiations, looking for ways to avoid another stalemate. If, as expected, the newly formed Unidos Podemos alliance surges to a clear second place, will the PSOE be prepared to make a deal with PP as the lesser of two evils? It's likely - they would appear to have very little to gain from a third vote. 
Polls may be suggesting a similar outcome to December's election, but that's by no means certain. School holidays may favor PP and disadvantage Podemos. The Brexit vote is 3 days beforehand. Obama is visiting in July. The democratic process is at risk if the electorate loses faith in the value of their vote. And then there's EU pressure over the tanking economy. . .
It's a far more complex and uncertain situation than my forecast suggests, but there is a real need for resolution and if that means a couple of parties need to make concessions, so be it.

Thinking about it more, I missed one permutation which is that of a leadership challenge in the PP (18% for now until I can do more work). That changes my forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/254236) to the following:
PP and Cuidadanos don't get a majority 78% 
Rajoy stays as leader (82%)
Sanchez's PSOE don't support them: 64% x 38%* - 24% 
New leader's (presumably Diaz) PSOE don't support them: 32% x 62%* - 20% 
Unidos Podemos don't support them: 99% 
Pro-independence Catalan or Basque parties don't support them: 98%

http://www.elmundo.es/espana.html
These numbers show a PSOE-Podemos coalition a few short if they can agree to play together nicely, which is not a gimme. Some of the regionals may step in, and of course numbers can change pretty quickly.  Seems like better odds this time than last time, and there are still some improbable combos that could come together.  However, it would be best not to underrate the potential for temper tantrums or sulking or other forms of intransigence on the part of some or all of the players.

Revisiting my initial analysis from http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/253994 : 
I'm increasing the odds of PSOE supporting a PP/CUI government from 10% (of the total) to 30% (of the total).
Situation is chaotic, possibly only after new polls. Again.

Polls show that there will be movement in the number of seats awarded to each party but it will be fairly limited, so while there are multiple ways this question resolves, there is only one way the question doesn't which is
PP and Ciudadanos don't get a majority and no other party supports them (either by abstaining/voting for them/joining coalition.

Polls indicate that the gridlock will continue.
Only thing new is that the joint ticket in the far left will win a few seats for Unidos Podemos from PSOE. But the right x left balance is virtually unchanged.
However, as a third election is so undesirable to all political actors, PSOE could abstain and allow a minority PP (or PP-Ciudadanos) government. 
Must admit that confidence is low and I'm ready to change my mind at first evidence of change in polls.

As it stands, the polls (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Spanish_general_election,_2016) predict results similar to the December 2015 election albeit with the the Podemos led alliance in second place, instead of PSOE. This means no party has enough to form a government on its own, and more importantly no two left parties or right parties (categorizing Cuidadanos as right since they are to the right of Podemos and PSOE) have enough to form a government together. This leaves two possibilities:

1- Things change in the next two weeks and either the left or the right "surges" ahead to get more than 50% of the seats. Let's assign this event a 40% chance.  If it's the right surging ahead (20% of the total), I think it would be easier for PP and Cuidadanos to either form a coalition or to have a PP government propped up by Cuidadanos (15% of the total). Otherwise if it's the left surging ahead (20%), it could be a little harder since chances are PSOE will have to be the junior partner unless Podemos concedes (10%? of the total). In short, while I'm assigning a 40% chance of a left or right tilt, I'm only assigning a 25% chance that this leads to a government.

So far the polls are showing PP with the lead, but not by enough to get in without help.  PSOE are becoming increasingly irrelevant, it seems.  Starting fairly low, but I'm prepared to move as quickly as I can at my age if things start to move.
